intro: Oxytropis hystrix, commonly known as the bristly milkvetch, is a perennial flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its upright growth habit and hairy, bristly stems. The plant produces small, pea-like flowers that are typically pink or purple in color, blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are compound, consisting of several small, oval-shaped leaflets, and it has a deep root system that helps it thrive in arid environments. Oxytropis hystrix is often found in rocky or gravelly soils and is adapted to withstand harsh climatic conditions.
